item.title: Recursion, Re-implementing underscore.js, Data Structures
item.description:
I've only been at MakerSquare for four days and it feels like four weeks. And I mean that in the best possible way!

In the past four days, I've done the following:

  • Learned what recursion is and how to write recursive functions
  • Implemented 15 underscore.js functions
  • Implemented stack and
item.dc:creator: Ryan Reynolds
item.content:encoded:
I've only been at MakerSquare for four days and it feels like four weeks. And I mean that in the best possible way!

In the past four days, I've done the following:

  • Learned what recursion is and how to write recursive functions
  • Implemented 15 underscore.js functions
  • Implemented stack and queue using the four instantiation patterns
    • functional
    • functional-shared
    • prototypal
    • pseudoclassical
  • Utilized pair programming as both driver and navigator for all of the above (I really like coding this way!)
  • Learned about lexical scoping and closure
  • Used github daily to push my code to my repos
  • Learned how to create an algorithm to solve a problem
  • Went over coding best practices
  • Examined function binding and how to use "this"

Phew!

item.title: First Steps Toward Becoming a Web Developer
item.description: After five years of practicing law, I quit my corporate law job to decide what I wanted to do with my life. I was never happy drafting contracts on a daily basis, so I wanted to take a step back to reflect on what I do enjoy doing so I
item.dc:creator: Ryan Reynolds
item.content:encoded:
After five years of practicing law, I quit my corporate law job to decide what I wanted to do with my life. I was never happy drafting contracts on a daily basis, so I wanted to take a step back to reflect on what I do enjoy doing so I could find a way to incorporate that in to my next job. So here we are after six or so months of soul searching, and a love of technology combined with a desire to build something in order to scratch that creative itch that wasn't satisfied while practicing law has led me to web development. Thus, the name for this blog - a mix of Lorem Ipsum (developer pseudo latin nonsense) and Res Ipsa Loquitur (a legal term meaning "the thing speaks for itself") - so roughly translating to Lorem Ipsum Speaks.

Monday was my first day at MakerSquare, a coding school in LA that focuses on JavaScript. My experience with coding before this was a month of self study followed by a month of night class to make sure I wanted to make the time and financial commitment that is being a student at MakerSquare. I really enjoyed coding and so here I am just starting a marathon to learn as much about JavaScript as I can 12 to 14 hours a day, six days a week, for the next three months - so all told roughly around 1000 hours.

I am starting this blog to keep track of what I'm learning since the days are already flying by and the pace is breakneck so I don't want to look back six weeks from now and forget how I got there.
